name: Lavender (oral)
summary: Oral lavender preparations, particularly standardized essential oil capsules, have been studied for their calming and anxiolytic properties, showing benefits in reducing anxiety, improving sleep, and promoting relaxation.
description: Lavender (*Lavandula angustifolia*) has a long history of use in traditional medicine for relaxation and calming. Oral forms, such as lavender oil capsules (notably standardized to contain linalool and linalyl acetate), have been clinically studied for generalized anxiety disorder, subsyndromal anxiety, and stress-related sleep disturbances. Evidence suggests lavender may modulate GABAergic neurotransmission, serotonin activity, and the autonomic nervous system. Compared to sedative medications, lavender is non-sedating and generally well tolerated, though gastrointestinal side effects can occur.

off_label_uses: Somatic symptoms related to stress (e.g., palpitations, GI distress)
contraindications: Known allergy to lavender or other Lamiaceae family plants
Concurrent use of strong sedatives (possible additive effects)

sections.text: Oral lavender oil may modulate neurotransmitters including GABA and serotonin, regulate autonomic nervous system activity, and reduce stress hormone release. Constituents such as linalool and linalyl acetate are believed to underlie its anxiolytic effects.

adult.typical: 80 mg of standardized lavender oil (Silexan) once daily

sections.pediatric: Not well studied; use not routinely recommended

sections.text: Anxiolytic effects may be observed within 1–2 weeks; full effects typically seen after 4–6 weeks of daily use.

serious: Rare hepatotoxicity reports in combination products

other: Avoid in individuals with known lavender allergy
May cause mild drowsiness in sensitive individuals
Not recommended as a replacement for prescription anxiolytics in severe cases

sections.pregnancy: Safety not well established; use with caution
sections.lactation: Limited safety data; avoid unless supervised
sections.pediatrics: Not recommended due to insufficient evidence
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe; monitor for sedation and GI effects

sections.text: No tapering required; effects diminish upon discontinuation.

items: Silexan (a standardized lavender oil preparation) has the strongest clinical evidence, showing efficacy comparable to low-dose lorazepam in some studies.
Lavender oral oil is non-sedating compared to benzodiazepines and antihistamines.
Most benefits are seen in mild to moderate anxiety rather than severe cases.

items.label: Kasper et al., 2010 – Lavender oil in GAD (RCT)

seo.title: Lavender Oral – Herbal Supplement for Anxiety and Sleep Support
seo.description: Oral lavender oil (e.g., Silexan) is a supplement studied for anxiety, stress, and sleep support. Learn about benefits, dosage, mechanisms, and safety.
